shoot.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to deliberately kill or injure someone using a gun
shoot.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Police shot one suspect when he pulled a gun on them.
Smith killed his wife, and then shot himself.
A woman was shot dead in an attempted robbery.
The guards have orders to shoot intruders on sight (=shoot them as soon as they see them).
He had been shot in the back while trying to escape.
shoot somebody in the leg/head etc
shoot.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to make a bullet or arrow come from a weapon
shoot.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Don’t shoot! I’m coming out with my hands up.
The soldiers had orders to shoot to kill (=shoot at someone with the intention of killing them).
They shot arrows from behind the thick bushes.
Tod’s grandfather taught him to shoot a rifle.
Two guys walked in and started shooting at people.
shoot.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to shoot and kill animals or birds as a sport
shoot.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: They spent the weekend in Scotland shooting grouse.
shoot.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to move quickly in a particular direction, or to make something move in this way
shoot.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: She shot past me into the house.
The cat shot across the garden.
‘Where does cotton come from?’ Ron’s hand shot up. ‘America, Miss!’
The fountain shoots water 20 feet into the air.
shoot.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to kick or throw a ball in a sport such as football or basketball towards the place where you can get a point
shoot.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Giggs shot from the halfway line.
shoot.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to take photographs or make a film of something
shoot.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The movie was shot in New Zealand.
shoot.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: if pain shoots through your body, you feel it going quickly through it
shoot.translation[0].definitions[6].note: shooting pains (=continuous short pains passing through your body)
shoot.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: A sharp pain suddenly shot along his arm.
shoot.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: if a plant shoots, a new part of it starts to grow, especially a new stem and leaves
shoot.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: to move the bolt on a door so that it is in the locked or unlocked position
shoot.translation[0].note_box[0].section: shoot
to use a gun to fire bullets, or to kill or injure someone using a gun
He ordered his men to stop shooting.
The guards shot the man as he was trying to escape.
President Kennedy was shot by a lone gunman.
to shoot bullets from a gun, or send an explosive object towards someone or something
Soldiers fired into the crowd.
Helicopters fired rockets at several buildings.
He regained his balance, took aim, and fired.
The police fired into the air to make the crowd break up.
As soon as we crossed the border, enemy troops started firing at us.
Kendrick fired three shots at the president’s car.
Suddenly the car stopped, and the passenger got out and fired a Kalashnikov rifle at the police car.
launch
to send a large rocket or missile into the air
American warships launched cruise missiles.
The guerrillas launched their rockets from densely populated towns.
open fire
to start shooting
Nineteen students were injured after a gunman opened fire.
Troops opened fire on a group of unarmed demonstrators.
The colonel gave the order for the soldiers to open fire.
shell
to fire shells  (=metal containers filled with an explosive substance) at enemy soldiers, cities etc in a war, using large guns
Border towns have been shelled by enemy aircraft for the past two months.
British warships began shelling German positions along the coast.
bombard
to attack a place for a long time with shells or bombs
Allied forces bombarded the coast prior to the invasion.
Troops bombarded the area with shells.
The allied forces bombarded the enemy trenches for weeks.
Cromwell’s men had been bombarding the fort with their artillery for several days.
take a potshot at somebody/something
to shoot at someone or something without aiming very carefully
Someone tried to take a potshot at him, but hit the man behind instead.
shoot.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: used to tell someone to start speaking
shoot.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the part of a plant that comes up above the ground when it is just beginning to grow, or a new part that grows on an existing plant
shoot.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Tender green shoots will appear in February.
shoot.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: an occasion when someone takes photographs or makes a film
shoot.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: a photo shoot sponsored by Kodak
She’s out on a video shoot.
shoot.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: an occasion when people shoot birds or animals for sport, or the area of land where they do this
shoot.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The royal party was on a shoot when the incident occurred.
shoot.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: used to show that you are annoyed or disappointed about something
shoot.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Oh, shoot! I forgot to buy milk.
shoot.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: to quickly increase in number or amount
shoot.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: Oil prices shot above $40 a barrel.
The monthly interest rate shot to 10% in January.
